values.description:
## Summary

* Add `--gui-config` option
* Change the destination of files saved with `Save configuration` to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`
* Copy the installed config file `install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/gui/gui.config` to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config` in case that doesn't exist
* The default SDF file loaded with `ign gazebo` doesn't have GUI embedded into it anymore. It will use the default config file instead.
* Added an example world that doesn't have `<gui>`, so loading it will use the default config

## Overview

There are a few places where the GUI configuration can come from. When Ignition Gazebo's GUI is started, the following happens:

1. If the user passed a configuration file from the command line using `--gui-config`, use that file and ignore the `<gui>` element from the SDF. Otherwise:
1. Use the `<gui>` element from the SDF. But in case that doesn't have any plugins:
1. Load the default config file at `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`. If this file doesn't exist, the `gui.config` file installed with Ignition Gazebo is copied there first.

When the user chooses `Save client configuration`, that will save the current configuration to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`, essentially setting that to the current view.

## Example usage

### Default config

You can change default plugins and style :art:. For example:

1. Start `ign gazebo` as usual - it doesn't have an entity tree and uses a light theme
1. Insert the `EntityTree` from the plugin's menu
1. `Style settings` -> change to dark theme
1. `Save client configuration` from the left menu
1. Close Gazebo
1. Start `ign gazebo` -> now it has an entity tree and uses the dark theme by default.

To restore the default configuration, delete the default file:

`rm ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`

The new world `default.sdf` serves as an example of how users can create worlds that don't have their own GUIs and use the default one instead. Try:

`ign gazebo default.sdf`

### Custom configs

To change the config to be used with a specific world:

1. Load the world, for example: `ign gazebo shapes.sdf`
1. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
1. `Save client configuration as...` file name `/tmp/shapes.config`
1. Close Gazebo
1. Start the same world, but using the saved config: `ign gazebo shapes.sdf --gui-config /tmp/shapes.config`

### Load configs

You can load saved configs at runtime, but that currently has a few caveats:

* Ogre 1 scenes get distorted after reload
* Ogre 2 scenes don't get properly reloaded
* Trying to mix Ogre 1 and 2 is a disaster (crash :boom:)

1. Load the world, for example: `ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf`
1. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
1. `Save client configuration as...` file name `/tmp/rolling_shapes.config`
1. Close Gazebo
1. Load the world with the SDF's config again, i.e.: `ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf`
1. `Load client configuration`: `/tmp/rolling_shapes.config` - all plugins get reloaded, but the 3D scene needs work.


## Known issues

* :warning: **The config files usually have the world name hardcoded in them.** This means that things will not work if the world name in the SDF doesn't match the config.
* Loading configs at runtime usually breaks the rendering scene. I started looking into it, but I think it falls outside the scope of this PR.

Once the scene reload issues are sorted out, we should write a tutorial about all this.
values.title: Improvements to GUI configuration

summary.raw:
## Summary

* Add `--gui-config` option
* Change the destination of files saved with `Save configuration` to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`
* Copy the installed config file `install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/gui/gui.config` to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config` in case that doesn't exist
* The default SDF file loaded with `ign gazebo` doesn't have GUI embedded into it anymore. It will use the default config file instead.
* Added an example world that doesn't have `<gui>`, so loading it will use the default config

## Overview

There are a few places where the GUI configuration can come from. When Ignition Gazebo's GUI is started, the following happens:

1. If the user passed a configuration file from the command line using `--gui-config`, use that file and ignore the `<gui>` element from the SDF. Otherwise:
1. Use the `<gui>` element from the SDF. But in case that doesn't have any plugins:
1. Load the default config file at `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`. If this file doesn't exist, the `gui.config` file installed with Ignition Gazebo is copied there first.

When the user chooses `Save client configuration`, that will save the current configuration to `~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`, essentially setting that to the current view.

## Example usage

### Default config

You can change default plugins and style :art:. For example:

1. Start `ign gazebo` as usual - it doesn't have an entity tree and uses a light theme
1. Insert the `EntityTree` from the plugin's menu
1. `Style settings` -> change to dark theme
1. `Save client configuration` from the left menu
1. Close Gazebo
1. Start `ign gazebo` -> now it has an entity tree and uses the dark theme by default.

To restore the default configuration, delete the default file:

`rm ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config`

The new world `default.sdf` serves as an example of how users can create worlds that don't have their own GUIs and use the default one instead. Try:

`ign gazebo default.sdf`

### Custom configs

To change the config to be used with a specific world:

1. Load the world, for example: `ign gazebo shapes.sdf`
1. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
1. `Save client configuration as...` file name `/tmp/shapes.config`
1. Close Gazebo
1. Start the same world, but using the saved config: `ign gazebo shapes.sdf --gui-config /tmp/shapes.config`

### Load configs

You can load saved configs at runtime, but that currently has a few caveats:

* Ogre 1 scenes get distorted after reload
* Ogre 2 scenes don't get properly reloaded
* Trying to mix Ogre 1 and 2 is a disaster (crash :boom:)

1. Load the world, for example: `ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf`
1. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
1. `Save client configuration as...` file name `/tmp/rolling_shapes.config`
1. Close Gazebo
1. Load the world with the SDF's config again, i.e.: `ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf`
1. `Load client configuration`: `/tmp/rolling_shapes.config` - all plugins get reloaded, but the 3D scene needs work.


## Known issues

* :warning: **The config files usually have the world name hardcoded in them.** This means that things will not work if the world name in the SDF doesn't match the config.
* Loading configs at runtime usually breaks the rendering scene. I started looking into it, but I think it falls outside the scope of this PR.

Once the scene reload issues are sorted out, we should write a tutorial about all this.
summary.html:
Summary

  • Add --gui-config option
  • Change the destination of files saved with Save configuration to ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config
  • Copy the installed config file install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/gui/gui.config to ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config in case that doesn't exist
  • The default SDF file loaded with ign gazebo doesn't have GUI embedded into it anymore. It will use the default config file instead.
  • Added an example world that doesn't have <gui>, so loading it will use the default config

Overview

There are a few places where the GUI configuration can come from. When Ignition Gazebo's GUI is started, the following happens:

  1. If the user passed a configuration file from the command line using --gui-config, use that file and ignore the <gui> element from the SDF. Otherwise:
  2. Use the <gui> element from the SDF. But in case that doesn't have any plugins:
  3. Load the default config file at ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config. If this file doesn't exist, the gui.config file installed with Ignition Gazebo is copied there first.

When the user chooses Save client configuration, that will save the current configuration to ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config, essentially setting that to the current view.

Example usage

Default config

You can change default plugins and style . For example:

  1. Start ign gazebo as usual - it doesn't have an entity tree and uses a light theme
  2. Insert the EntityTree from the plugin's menu
  3. Style settings -> change to dark theme
  4. Save client configuration from the left menu
  5. Close Gazebo
  6. Start ign gazebo -> now it has an entity tree and uses the dark theme by default.

To restore the default configuration, delete the default file:

rm ~/.ignition/gazebo/gui.config

The new world default.sdf serves as an example of how users can create worlds that don't have their own GUIs and use the default one instead. Try:

ign gazebo default.sdf

Custom configs

To change the config to be used with a specific world:

  1. Load the world, for example: ign gazebo shapes.sdf
  2. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
  3. Save client configuration as... file name /tmp/shapes.config
  4. Close Gazebo
  5. Start the same world, but using the saved config: ign gazebo shapes.sdf --gui-config /tmp/shapes.config

Load configs

You can load saved configs at runtime, but that currently has a few caveats:

  • Ogre 1 scenes get distorted after reload
  • Ogre 2 scenes don't get properly reloaded
  • Trying to mix Ogre 1 and 2 is a disaster (crash )
  1. Load the world, for example: ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf
  2. Resize the window, remove and add plugins
  3. Save client configuration as... file name /tmp/rolling_shapes.config
  4. Close Gazebo
  5. Load the world with the SDF's config again, i.e.: ign gazebo rolling_shapes.sdf
  6. Load client configuration: /tmp/rolling_shapes.config - all plugins get reloaded, but the 3D scene needs work.

Known issues

  • The config files usually have the world name hardcoded in them. This means that things will not work if the world name in the SDF doesn't match the config.
  • Loading configs at runtime usually breaks the rendering scene. I started looking into it, but I think it falls outside the scope of this PR.

Once the scene reload issues are sorted out, we should write a tutorial about all this.

values.description:
Changes needed for marker demo to work with the ogre2 version of markers in ign-rendering, see [ign-rendering pull request #208](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/208)

* use diffuse \(in addition to ambient\) - ambient is not used by PBR
* check null geometry - ogre2 version of dynamic renderables is not supported yet so a null geom is returned if the marker render type is set to anything other than simple shapes, e.g. points, lines, etc

‌
values.title: Marker port for ogre2

summary.raw:
Changes needed for marker demo to work with the ogre2 version of markers in ign-rendering, see [ign-rendering pull request #208](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/208)

* use diffuse \(in addition to ambient\) - ambient is not used by PBR
* check null geometry - ogre2 version of dynamic renderables is not supported yet so a null geom is returned if the marker render type is set to anything other than simple shapes, e.g. points, lines, etc

‌
summary.html:
Changes needed for marker demo to work with the ogre2 version of markers in ign-rendering, see ign-rendering pull request #208

  • use diffuse (in addition to ambient) - ambient is not used by PBR
  • check null geometry - ogre2 version of dynamic renderables is not supported yet so a null geom is returned if the marker render type is set to anything other than simple shapes, e.g. points, lines, etc

‌

values.description:
depends on

* [ignition-rendering pull request #210](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/210/backport-setting-cast-shadows/diff) \(merged)
* [sdformat pull request #590](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/590/update-visual-dom-to-parse-cast_shadows/diff) \(merged\)

Note: I accidentally pushed to `ign-gazebo2` branch in [0d474da](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/0d474daa66a40b0257ccf141659f5bf975f58573) but backed out the changes in [87d35b9](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/87d35b9db3135701c15b7d3133585b39dcc073be)

The changes let users specify whether a visual casts shadows through the `cast_shadows` sdf element of a visual.

The camera\_sensor.sdf example world is updated to include a sphere that does not cast shadows. Sphere’s shadows should be disabled in both the GUI’s 3d scene and also in the view of the camera sensor.

‌
values.title: Parse visual cast shadows and add CastShadows component

Note: I accidentally pushed to `ign-gazebo2` branch in [0d474da](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/0d474daa66a40b0257ccf141659f5bf975f58573) but backed out the changes in [87d35b9](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/87d35b9db3135701c15b7d3133585b39dcc073be)

The changes let users specify whether a visual casts shadows through the `cast_shadows` sdf element of a visual.

The camera\_sensor.sdf example world is updated to include a sphere that does not cast shadows. Sphere’s shadows should be disabled in both the GUI’s 3d scene and also in the view of the camera sensor.

‌
summary.html:
depends on

  • ignition-rendering pull request #210 (merged)
  • sdformat pull request #590 (merged)

Note: I accidentally pushed to ign-gazebo2 branch in 0d474da but backed out the changes in 87d35b9

The changes let users specify whether a visual casts shadows through the cast_shadows sdf element of a visual.

The camera_sensor.sdf example world is updated to include a sphere that does not cast shadows. Sphere’s shadows should be disabled in both the GUI’s 3d scene and also in the view of the camera sensor.

‌

values.description:
Needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/591) SDF PR and goes with [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/web-app/pull-requests/143/) Fuel PR.

![dragme_trolley.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/338425706-dragme_trolley.gif)

You can test without Fuel by dragging the URL from anywhere. For example, select this and drag it:

`https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/openrobotics/models/TrolleyBed`

values.description:
Here we go again with the correct version!

Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters:

<enable\_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging\_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc\_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold
values.title: Rechargeable battery model

summary.raw:
Here we go again with the correct version!

Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters:

<enable\_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging\_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc\_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold
summary.html:
Here we go again with the correct version!

Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters:

<enable_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold

values.description:
This adds support for sdformat's frame semantics as described in the [pose frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&). 

This is done by resolving the poses of all SDF DOM objects relative to their default frames before assigning them to `component::Pose` components. This retains the existing behavior of pose components in that the relative-to frame of all poses is always the frame of the parent element except for joints, which use the child link frame.

**Dependencies:**
  
  * [libsdformat PR #602](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/602).
  * [ign-physics PR #106](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/106)
  * [ign-sensors PR #104](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/104)
  * ~~[ign-msgs PR #160](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/160)~~
values.title: [Citadel] Add support for sdformat frame semantics

summary.raw:
This adds support for sdformat's frame semantics as described in the [pose frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&). 

This is done by resolving the poses of all SDF DOM objects relative to their default frames before assigning them to `component::Pose` components. This retains the existing behavior of pose components in that the relative-to frame of all poses is always the frame of the parent element except for joints, which use the child link frame.

**Dependencies:**
  
  * [libsdformat PR #602](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/602).
  * [ign-physics PR #106](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/106)
  * [ign-sensors PR #104](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/104)
  * ~~[ign-msgs PR #160](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/160)~~
summary.html:
This adds support for sdformat's frame semantics as described in the pose frame semantics proposal.

This is done by resolving the poses of all SDF DOM objects relative to their default frames before assigning them to component::Pose components. This retains the existing behavior of pose components in that the relative-to frame of all poses is always the frame of the parent element except for joints, which use the child link frame.

Dependencies:

  • libsdformat PR #602.
  • ign-physics PR #106
  • ign-sensors PR #104
  • ign-msgs PR #160

values.title: Add option to right click and remove nodes

values.description:
A system for creating Breadcrumbs in the form of models that can get deployed/spawned at the location of the model to which this system is attached. Each breadcrumb is a complete `sdf::Model`. When deployed, the pose of the breadcrumb model is offset from the containing model by the pose specified in the `<pose>` element of the breadcrumb model. A name is generated for the breadcrumb by appending the current count of deployments to the name specified in the breadcrumb `<model>` element. The model specified in the `<breadcrumb>` parameter serves as a template for deploying multiple breadcrumbs of the same type. Including models from Fuel is accomplished by creating a `<model>` that includes the Fuel model using the `<include>` tag. See the example in examples/worlds/breadcrumbs.sdf.

## System Parameters

`<topic>`: Custom topic to be used to deploy breadcrumbs. If topic is not set, the default topic with the following pattern would be used "/model/<model\_name>/breadcrumbs/<breadcrumb\_name>/deploy". The topic type is `ignition.msgs.Empty`

`<max_deployments>`: The maximum number of times this breadcrumb can be deployed. Once this many are deployed, publishing on the deploy topic will have no effect. If a negative number is set, the maximum deployment will be unbounded.

`<breadcrumb>`: This is the model used as a template for deploying breadcrumbs.

**Example \(examples/worlds/breadcrumbs.sdf\)**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3647471147-ezgif.com-optimize.gif)
‌
values.title: Add Breadcrumbs system

The model specified in the `<breadcrumb>` parameter serves as a template for deploying multiple breadcrumbs of the same type. Including models from Fuel is accomplished by creating a `<model>` that includes the Fuel model using the `<include>` tag. See the example in examples/worlds/breadcrumbs.sdf.

`<topic>`: Custom topic to be used to deploy breadcrumbs. If topic is not set, the default topic with the following pattern would be used "/model/<model\_name>/breadcrumbs/<breadcrumb\_name>/deploy". The topic type is `ignition.msgs.Empty`

`<max_deployments>`: The maximum number of times this breadcrumb can be deployed. Once this many are deployed, publishing on the deploy topic will have no effect. If a negative number is set, the maximum deployment will be unbounded.

**Example \(examples/worlds/breadcrumbs.sdf\)**

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3647471147-ezgif.com-optimize.gif)
‌

A system for creating Breadcrumbs in the form of models that can get deployed/spawned at the location of the model to which this system is attached. Each breadcrumb is a complete sdf::Model. When deployed, the pose of the breadcrumb model is offset from the containing model by the pose specified in the <pose> element of the breadcrumb model. Including models from Fuel is accomplished by creating a <model> that includes the Fuel model using the <include> tag. See the example in examples/worlds/breadcrumbs.sdf.

System Parameters

<topic>: Custom topic to be used to deploy breadcrumbs. If topic is not set, the default topic with the following pattern would be used "/model/<model_name>/breadcrumbs/<breadcrumb_name>/deploy". The topic type is ignition.msgs.Empty

<max_deployments>: The maximum number of times this breadcrumb can be deployed. Once this many are deployed, publishing on the deploy topic will have no effect. If a negative number is set, the maximum deployment will be unbounded.

values.description: This PR allows users to enable grid view in sdf. Run `ign gazebo lights.sdf` to view grid in ogre. Currently grid is not implemented in ogre2. Run `ign gazebo camera_sensor.sdf` to test grid in user view and camera view \(need to lower object z-axis position to show grid\).
values.title: Show grid using sdf file

summary.raw: This PR allows users to enable grid view in sdf. Run `ign gazebo lights.sdf` to view grid in ogre. Currently grid is not implemented in ogre2. Run `ign gazebo camera_sensor.sdf` to test grid in user view and camera view \(need to lower object z-axis position to show grid\).
summary.html: This PR allows users to enable grid view in sdf. Run ign gazebo lights.sdf to view grid in ogre. Currently grid is not implemented in ogre2. Run ign gazebo camera_sensor.sdf to test grid in user view and camera view (need to lower object z-axis position to show grid).

values.description: Some components (eg. `components::ExternalWorldWrenchCmd`) use `ignition::msgs` types. This adds serialization for such components in the default serializer class.
values.title: Serialize components based on ignition::msgs with the default serializer

summary.raw: Some components (eg. `components::ExternalWorldWrenchCmd`) use `ignition::msgs` types. This adds serialization for such components in the default serializer class.
summary.html: Some components (eg. components::ExternalWorldWrenchCmd) use ignition::msgs types. This adds serialization for such components in the default serializer class.

values.description:
Just a temporary workaround so there's no crash if the user attempts to load more than one `Scene3D`, from the plugin menu, SDF or GUI config files.

I think that the ideal solution would detect that there's a render engine already loaded and use that one, or refuse to load a new one from the Ignition Rendering side. I remember looking a bit into doing this from rendering and getting nowhere, so I'm putting this workaround here for now.

Let me know if you have any ideas that are more elegant than this, @{iche033} .
values.title: Prevent crash when attempting to load more than one render engine per process

summary.raw:
Just a temporary workaround so there's no crash if the user attempts to load more than one `Scene3D`, from the plugin menu, SDF or GUI config files.

I think that the ideal solution would detect that there's a render engine already loaded and use that one, or refuse to load a new one from the Ignition Rendering side. I remember looking a bit into doing this from rendering and getting nowhere, so I'm putting this workaround here for now.

Let me know if you have any ideas that are more elegant than this, @{iche033} .
summary.html:
Just a temporary workaround so there's no crash if the user attempts to load more than one Scene3D, from the plugin menu, SDF or GUI config files.

I think that the ideal solution would detect that there's a render engine already loaded and use that one, or refuse to load a new one from the Ignition Rendering side. I remember looking a bit into doing this from rendering and getting nowhere, so I'm putting this workaround here for now.

Let me know if you have any ideas that are more elegant than this, @Ian Chen .

values.description:
The main changes are:

* ~~moved the code for handling the follow mode to earlier in the function before the render call.~~ Update in [489d6e7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/489d6e78349f45d7cc78372a8bfd7f611934a671):  Added extra checks before render call instead.
* trigger an event to set the follow target to empty string so that it clears the Qt message about pressing escape to exit follow mode

‌
values.title: Fix crash when removing an entity being followed

summary.raw:
The main changes are:

* ~~moved the code for handling the follow mode to earlier in the function before the render call.~~ Update in [489d6e7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/489d6e78349f45d7cc78372a8bfd7f611934a671):  Added extra checks before render call instead.
* trigger an event to set the follow target to empty string so that it clears the Qt message about pressing escape to exit follow mode

‌
summary.html:
The main changes are:

  • moved the code for handling the follow mode to earlier in the function before the render call. Update in 489d6e7: Added extra checks before render call instead.
  • trigger an event to set the follow target to empty string so that it clears the Qt message about pressing escape to exit follow mode

‌

values.title: Add grid view to Citadel
values.reason: Grid merged forward from ign-gazebo2, scene deprecations postponed.

values.description:
The spelling mistake \(`achors`\) was responsible for the following warning msgs:

```
[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/GzScene3D/GzScene3D.qml:59: TypeError: Cannot read property 'left' of undefined
[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/GzScene3D/GzScene3D.qml:58: TypeError: Cannot read property 'top' of undefined
```

turns out we don’t need these anchors. The text label displayed when in camera follow mode correctly defaults to the top left corner. So the anchors are removed.

‌
values.title: Remove Scene3d Text anchors

[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/GzScene3D/GzScene3D.qml:58: TypeError: Cannot read property 'top' of undefined
```

turns out we don’t need these anchors. The text label displayed when in camera follow mode correctly defaults to the top left corner. So the anchors are removed.

values.description: There's a lot of room for improvement on this tutorial. A lot of pieces are presented, but the reader still needs to figure out how to put them all together. I just updated it for Citadel and added a snippet of the `.cc` code, but I think we need to revisit this and provide the reader with a full recipe for building and running a plugin.

values.description:
NOTE: The custom snap values PR (#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/493) needs to be merged before this one can be.

Ready for review

Adds all hotkeys seen at http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys under the `Manipulating Models` category except for `Snap when inserting` and `Snap models together`

Specifically:

* Adds key presses for switching between selection (ESC), translation (t), rotation (r), scaling (s)

* Adds 1m snapping for translation when holding CTRL

* Adds 45 degree snapping for rotation when holding CTRL

* Adds 0.5 scale snapping when scaling when holding CTRL (support was added even though scaling is not yet a feature)

* Constrains along the x, y, or z axis when holding those respective keys while dragging

* Transforming via world frame when holding Shift
values.title: Add keybindings

summary.raw:
NOTE: The custom snap values PR (#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/493) needs to be merged before this one can be.

Ready for review

Adds all hotkeys seen at http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys under the `Manipulating Models` category except for `Snap when inserting` and `Snap models together`

Specifically:

* Adds key presses for switching between selection (ESC), translation (t), rotation (r), scaling (s)

* Adds 1m snapping for translation when holding CTRL

* Adds 45 degree snapping for rotation when holding CTRL

* Adds 0.5 scale snapping when scaling when holding CTRL (support was added even though scaling is not yet a feature)

* Constrains along the x, y, or z axis when holding those respective keys while dragging

* Transforming via world frame when holding Shift
summary.html:
NOTE: The custom snap values PR (#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/493) needs to be merged before this one can be.

Ready for review

Adds all hotkeys seen at http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys under the Manipulating Models category except for Snap when inserting and Snap models together

Specifically:

  • Adds key presses for switching between selection (ESC), translation (t), rotation (r), scaling (s)

  • Adds 1m snapping for translation when holding CTRL

  • Adds 45 degree snapping for rotation when holding CTRL

  • Adds 0.5 scale snapping when scaling when holding CTRL (support was added even though scaling is not yet a feature)

  • Constrains along the x, y, or z axis when holding those respective keys while dragging

  • Transforming via world frame when holding Shift

values.description:
This adds the a velocity controller based on the [Lee position controller from rotorS](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator/blob/master/rotors_control/src/library/lee_position_controller.cpp). The controller takes linear velocity and yaw angle velocity commands in the body frame of the vehicle.

## Try it

```
ign gazebo -v 4 -r  examples/worlds/quadcopter.sdf 
```

```
ign topic -t "/X3/gazebo/command/twist" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {z: 0.1}"
```

Wait a few seconds and

```
ign topic -t "/X3/gazebo/command/twist" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x:0.1}"
```

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1750270278-ezgif.com-resize.gif)
## Todo:

* ~~Documentation~~

‌
values.title: Multicopter velocity control

```

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1750270278-ezgif.com-resize.gif)
## Todo:

* ~~Documentation~~

‌
summary.html:
This adds the a velocity controller based on the Lee position controller from rotorS. The controller takes linear velocity and yaw angle velocity commands in the body frame of the vehicle.

Try it

ign gazebo -v 4 -r  examples/worlds/quadcopter.sdf 

ign topic -t "/X3/gazebo/command/twist" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {z: 0.1}"

Wait a few seconds and

ign topic -t "/X3/gazebo/command/twist" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x:0.1}"

Todo:

  • Documentation

‌

values.description:
Log file recording is fine. Log file playback was affected by pull request #450. What happened is that the SceneBroadcaster sends out a new message at 60Hz using the wall clock. 60Hz wall clock updates do not always coincide with LogPlayback updates. The result is jumpy playback.

This PR forces a "change" every time the state is updated.
values.title: Fix jumpy log playback

summary.raw:
Log file recording is fine. Log file playback was affected by pull request #450. What happened is that the SceneBroadcaster sends out a new message at 60Hz using the wall clock. 60Hz wall clock updates do not always coincide with LogPlayback updates. The result is jumpy playback.

This PR forces a "change" every time the state is updated.
summary.html:
Log file recording is fine. Log file playback was affected by pull request #450. What happened is that the SceneBroadcaster sends out a new message at 60Hz using the wall clock. 60Hz wall clock updates do not always coincide with LogPlayback updates. The result is jumpy playback.

This PR forces a "change" every time the state is updated.

values.description:
Since the context menu was added, the tooltips were not showing up properly because the context menu's `MouseArea` was swallowing the hover events. This PR fixes this so both tooltip and context menu work:

![tooltip_contextmenu.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/435607593-tooltip_contextmenu.gif)

values.description:
This splits off the overwrite feature from PR #397.

# Testing --log-overwrite

Similar tests have been added to integration test, especially because there are subtle differences between each test case, and it will be hard to remember them all manually in the future.

1\. No `--log-overwrite` \(default\):

Note in Citadel, we log to the `<path>` specified in SDF. In future versions, recording will be logged to the same directory as the console log directory initialized in `ign.cc`.

```
# This SDF specifies the equivalent of --record-path '/tmp/log'
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
```

2\. `--log-overwrite`, `/tmp/log` already exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

3\. No path specified anywhere, should log to default path:

Comment out `<path></path>` in the SDF, then run it:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf
```

Recording should go to `$HOME/.ignition/…` default path.

4\. Specify one path in SDF, another path on command line, should log to the path on command line:

Double check that `<path>` in SDF says `/tmp/log`.

Specify a different path on command line. The path on command line should be taken over the path in SDF:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --record-path '/tmp/logging'
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/logging/state.tlog]
```

‌
values.title: Log record overwrite

# Testing --log-overwrite

Similar tests have been added to integration test, especially because there are subtle differences between each test case, and it will be hard to remember them all manually in the future.

1\. No `--log-overwrite` \(default\):

Note in Citadel, we log to the `<path>` specified in SDF. In future versions, recording will be logged to the same directory as the console log directory initialized in `ign.cc`.

```

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf

2\. `--log-overwrite`, `/tmp/log` already exists:

...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

3\. No path specified anywhere, should log to default path:

Comment out `<path></path>` in the SDF, then run it:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf
```

Recording should go to `$HOME/.ignition/…` default path.

4\. Specify one path in SDF, another path on command line, should log to the path on command line:

summary.html:
This splits off the overwrite feature from PR #397.

Testing --log-overwrite

Similar tests have been added to integration test, especially because there are subtle differences between each test case, and it will be hard to remember them all manually in the future.

1. No --log-overwrite (default):

Note in Citadel, we log to the <path> specified in SDF. In future versions, recording will be logged to the same directory as the console log directory initialized in ign.cc.

# This SDF specifies the equivalent of --record-path '/tmp/log'
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]

2. --log-overwrite, /tmp/log already exists:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording

3. No path specified anywhere, should log to default path:

Comment out <path></path> in the SDF, then run it:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf

Recording should go to $HOME/.ignition/… default path.

4. Specify one path in SDF, another path on command line, should log to the path on command line:

Double check that <path> in SDF says /tmp/log.

Specify a different path on command line. The path on command line should be taken over the path in SDF:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --record-path '/tmp/logging'
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/logging/state.tlog]

values.description: This addresses [SubT issue 307](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/issues/307) by using a component to communicate between the `MulticopterVelocityControl` and `MulticopterMotorModel` systems. The root problem was that control messages were arriving late due to a blocking disk write in the ign-transport log recorder. The solution in this PR is to avoid using transport for control messages.
values.title: Use Actuator component to communicate between MulticopterVelocityControl and MulticopterMotorModel systems

summary.raw: This addresses [SubT issue 307](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/issues/307) by using a component to communicate between the `MulticopterVelocityControl` and `MulticopterMotorModel` systems. The root problem was that control messages were arriving late due to a blocking disk write in the ign-transport log recorder. The solution in this PR is to avoid using transport for control messages.
summary.html: This addresses SubT issue 307 by using a component to communicate between the MulticopterVelocityControl and MulticopterMotorModel systems. The root problem was that control messages were arriving late due to a blocking disk write in the ign-transport log recorder. The solution in this PR is to avoid using transport for control messages.

values.description:
We made some changes to the `ign gazebo` tool which broke the deprecated `ign-gazebo` tool. This PR ports the default config from pull request #451, as well as the new plugin loading from pull request #285.

Now the `ign-gazebo` tool should work again, i.e. `ign-gazebo -v 4 -f rolling_shapes.sdf`.
values.title: Fix ign-gazebo command line tool

summary.raw:
We made some changes to the `ign gazebo` tool which broke the deprecated `ign-gazebo` tool. This PR ports the default config from pull request #451, as well as the new plugin loading from pull request #285.

Now the `ign-gazebo` tool should work again, i.e. `ign-gazebo -v 4 -f rolling_shapes.sdf`.
summary.html:
We made some changes to the ign gazebo tool which broke the deprecated ign-gazebo tool. This PR ports the default config from pull request #451, as well as the new plugin loading from pull request #285.

Now the ign-gazebo tool should work again, i.e. ign-gazebo -v 4 -f rolling_shapes.sdf.

values.description:
This splits off the compress feature from PR #397.

Added tests for compress, and compress \+ overwrite. The tests that set flags programmatically test the new logic in `ServerPrivate.cc`. The tests run from command line the new logic in `ign.cc`, e.g. unique paths e.g. `*(1)` are defined in `ign.cc` when no overwrite flag is specified.

They are equivalent to these tests:

1\. --log-compress to default path

2\. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log exists, /tmp/log.zip does not exist

3\. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists

4\. --log-compress only, both /tmp/log and /tmp/log.zip already exist

5\. --log-compress only, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists, /tmp/log\(1\).zip exists
values.title: Log compress

summary.raw:
This splits off the compress feature from PR #397.

Added tests for compress, and compress \+ overwrite. The tests that set flags programmatically test the new logic in `ServerPrivate.cc`. The tests run from command line the new logic in `ign.cc`, e.g. unique paths e.g. `*(1)` are defined in `ign.cc` when no overwrite flag is specified.

They are equivalent to these tests:

1\. --log-compress to default path

2\. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log exists, /tmp/log.zip does not exist

3\. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists

4\. --log-compress only, both /tmp/log and /tmp/log.zip already exist

5\. --log-compress only, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists, /tmp/log\(1\).zip exists
summary.html:
This splits off the compress feature from PR #397.

Added tests for compress, and compress + overwrite. The tests that set flags programmatically test the new logic in ServerPrivate.cc. The tests run from command line the new logic in ign.cc, e.g. unique paths e.g. *(1) are defined in ign.cc when no overwrite flag is specified.

They are equivalent to these tests:

1. --log-compress to default path

2. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log exists, /tmp/log.zip does not exist

3. --log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists

4. --log-compress only, both /tmp/log and /tmp/log.zip already exist

5. --log-compress only, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists, /tmp/log(1).zip exists
